transcript:
Welcome to Behind the Ticker.
I'm Brad Roth, chief investment officer of Thor Financial Technologies, and portfolio manager
of THLV, the Thor Low Volatility ETF.
Behind the Ticker, uncovers the inner workings of the ETF industry.
We will interview portfolio managers and ETF service providers to dive deep into their
work lives and their businesses.
We will learn the inner workings of their strategies and what drives them as they continue
to grow their company.
Many of these individuals are entrepreneurs, and will have unique and compelling insights
to share as much goes on behind the Ticker.
Please note, nothing in this show is investment advice, and it is meant solely for
educational and entertainment purposes only.
Welcome to Behind the Ticker.
Today we have Steve Cook.
He is the head of ETFs at Harbor Capital.
We talk about the business.
They got their start by sourcing investment managers.
Then dove into the fund management business, managing mutual funds, CITs, and a handful
of ETFs.
Steve has a ton of experience.
It was nice to talk to Steve.
We talked about NYSE floor listing, and we also talked deeply about their product hedgeer,
which is a all-weather commodity ETF, a little bit more active, and a little different
take on commodity exposure.
Without further ado, please welcome Steve Cook.
Hey Steve, welcome to the show.
Brad, good morning.
How you doing?
Thanks for having me.
I'm great.
Before we get started, can you talk a little bit about your background in your current
role at Harbor?
Sure.
Currently, I'm the head of ETFs for Harbor Capital Advisors, and kind of overseeing
the product selection, capital markets, and operations for the ETF business.
I got my start in ETFs a long time ago when the NASDAQ launched the QQQ, BNYBELL, and was selected
as the trustee.
And back in the early days of ETFs, before Reagan and MS, exchanges created the ETFs
to drive volumes onto their exchange.
But they didn't want to have the burden of a 40-act fund with a board, and register as an advisor,
all those sorts of things.
So, they registered the early ETFs as unit investment trusts, and they cast kind of all
the responsibility for operating the trust and ETF onto the trustee.
And so, Banking York was selected as a trustee, and I got to first hand look across the board.
The investment management piece for an index perspective of the capital markets and trading
piece, because there was no centralized data repository.
And so, the folks trading these things on the floor would call you for information and updates
on how what changes the ETF made made, and the basket knows what to think.
So, you really kind of got immersed in the ETF ecosystem through that, and that, that's how
I first got involved, and then had a number of roles within the ETF industry ever since.
Yeah, no, that's really interesting.
And before we kind of jump into more about Harbor and more about the ETF business, I always
like to ask everybody, would you like to do outside of the office, any hobbies or interests?
So, I enjoy playing golf.
I'm a big beach guy.
So, oftentimes people talk about lakes with beach.
If I'm not within like 20 minutes of the beach, I twitch, because I really like to go and
just hang out and enjoy it.
So, that's when I get free time, but most of the time right now, I drive my kids around
to competitive soccer tournaments and games.
Yeah, I'm just entering in the world of soccer.
I'm used seven girls right now, and I'm kind of dreading that step up into you eight, where
they start to travel, and just consumes your entire weekend.
Yeah, I'm at you 17 and you 15 right now.
So, we're going all up and down to East Coast and it's all kind of time consuming, but
it's a lot of fun.
I know it doesn't last forever, but it's quite quickly Brad, so enjoy it while you're
doing it.
Yeah, I love it.
I got baited into coaching this year, and I was like, I don't know anything about
soccer, but I think I can motivate kids, and I tell you what, it's like the most fun
I have all week is kind of not yelling at, but cheering for, you know, the
these girls during their games, it is a lot of fun.
So, so can you talk about Harbor Capital and the types of services you all provide?
Because it is a pretty interesting business as I kind of look into it, and so I'd love
for you to kind of talk more deeply about Harbor and everything you guys do over there.
Sure, so Harbor was formed initially as kind of the pension management arm of Libby
glass and a few other Ohio manufacturing companies 40 years ago, and it really focused
on manager selection to manage the pension assets and the executive team at Libby felt like
they were doing such a good job, and the manager selection was so on point that they said,
you know, why you spin out and become a professional mutual fund firm as a manager, manager,
selecting and finding asset management firms and niche areas and start mutual funds.
And so they did that primarily for the first 35 years of Harbor's existence, they were a mutual
fund shop that would go out and seek managers and specific asset classes and launch funds
with them.
And they had, we had a lot of success doing that.
We found we were the first to launch Pimco in a retail, you know, mutual fund structure.
So if you wanted access to Pimco, the only place you get that was to a Harbor mutual fund.
We have over a 50 year relationship with Genesis and Associates, a fantastic growth manager.
And that Harbor identified early on and we have our largest mutual fund with them, capital
and so that's kind of the DNA of Harbor is to go out and seek really strong managers and
specific asset classes where you as a retail investor may not be able to get access to them.
And that's what we did for 35 years and then, you know, as kind of the retail broker's
environment changed and shifted, Harbor first launched CITs about four years ago for the retirement
market and then made the decision to get in the ETFs for more the wealth market, you know,
as buyer behavior started to shift, you've seen a 10 year secular decline and investors
appetites for mutual fund and tilted more to ETFs. So we launched ETFs in September of 2021
with the same idea, you know, bring really unique products to market for investors that they
may not be able to get elsewhere and certainly with managers, they may not have access to elsewhere.
Yes, so that was the part that was interesting to me. So are you guys going out and sourcing
managers or managers coming to you and can you maybe talk a little bit about that due diligence
process if you know what it looks like? Sure, so it's a little bit of both. Initially we had to go out
and seek managers, you know, for our first few ETFs, you know, once you've gained a little bit of
success in the area then you start to get managers who reach out to you with ideas so it's a little
bit of a both. But either the way the same due diligence process is undertaken, we have an investment
research team that goes out and looks at manager ideas and overall managers and ensures that they
have the capability and history of generating alpha for investors in any particular asset class.
And so we're trying to look and make sure that whatever generated the alpha in the past is repeatable,
it's not wasn't just some sort of benchmark hugging where they got a little lucky and
tilted, so by some factor. And you know, the other real thing that we want to see and ensure
is that there's a constant process of improvement and that the managers have an underlying
desire to continue to develop whatever, you know, process, they're utilizing to generate
alpha to improve that over time. And so those are the two areas that we really dig in on and our
IRT team seeks out and does a wonderful job looking at it. And so, you know, either way, whether we
decide that we want to have a product that's unique in the small cap space or somebody comes to
us with an idea that says we've got the better way of providing access to commodities, you know,
what will undertake, but the research disciplines there in both respects.
So, can you talk about maybe the next steps there? So, let's say you've sourced or, you know,
found a manager that can run a unique strategy for you. You know, can you talk about that kind
ideation to actually getting the product to market and what that looks?
Yeah, so, you know, once we've determined that the idea, the thought process, the manager,
has the chops to deliver that alpha, then we work with them to understand what it takes to
manage and exchange traded fund. It is slightly different than either a non-registered product
or a mutual fund. So, we partner with them, we'll refine the idea, you know, maybe you have to
make a few tweaks in order to perfect the process within the ETF structure, you know, whether that's
the way they trade, the way they might rebalance, the number of securities that they hold,
you know, maybe you have to exclude an aim in order to make it more tradable,
those sorts of things. And so, we'll go back and forth generally for a few months
trying to perfect the process. And in that time, we're also helping them to understand
and update their technologies and their systems to be able to copy the ETF exchange
information and data that goes on. We're working with our service provider to pull them in
and then we're updating the necessary regulatory filings and exchanging information.
And so, all that generally takes, you know, three to six months
of working kind of behind the scenes. And, you know, then towards the end of the process, we're
out seeking a partner from a liquidity standpoint. And an AP standpoint, somebody has to help launch
and see the initial day one ETF. And so, we have a number of partners that we try and focus on.
We do try and keep that narrow though. You know, if we're ETF perspective as you well know,
you don't want to have 15 market-maker relationships for 15 products. It becomes unwieldy and very
difficult. And so, we seek partners for that and then we prepare for launch. And then we start thinking
about, you know, how are we going to market this? How are we going to get the word out to
advisors and the investing community that this product is coming or what it does show up?
You know, what makes it unique? You know, why do we launch it? How does it fit into an investor's
portfolio? And why don't we really think that there's a need for it?
Yeah. And I definitely want to talk a little bit about that later about how you guys are handling
distribution and marketing. But you, Harbour was one of the first to decide to move to NYSE floor.
I don't know if you remember, but you and I actually had a phone conversation because I saw the
move and I wanted to make, I wanted to, I was exploring that move as well. We eventually did it.
So, can you talk about why you decided to make that move to the NYSE floor and why we're seeing
more ETFs do it? Yeah. So, you know, it's funny after 25 years in the ETF space, you know,
you look back and you think, okay, there are certain things that everybody already understands
about ETFs and you take that for granted as somebody who's gonna live and breathe it every day.
And I think one of this more, um, and fact of things that we see currently is,
it's folks still understand how to trade some of these vehicles and understand necessarily the
wives, right? And so, um, you know, the constant preaching, you want to avoid the first 15 minutes
of trading in the ETF. You want to avoid the last 15 minutes of trading in ETF. And throughout the
course of the day for more thinly traded ETFs, as best you can, if you're not using a block order,
you want to use limit orders to avoid these widespread occurring in the product. And what happens
is, in the morning, you know, as all the underlying securities in ETF, let's say you're,
you're fund those, 115, all those 150 names, the markets for those individual securities and those
equities has to open. And as it's opening, there's price discovery going on and each one of those
individual equities could have, you know, a three-cent swing in its opening price. Well, you put
all that together and the broader swings for the actual ETF can be 15s. And it's nobody's fault
that's just the way the kind of market opens, particularly when you're utilizing computers to come
up. Um, computers are gonna assess the market, they can say, wow, these three equities are having
a hard time open. We need to widen out this ETF to protect ourselves against, uh, somebody who might
be trading it actively or professionally, um, to protect ourselves. And so, um, you know, those
first 15, it's going to be difficult. However, when you're introducing new advisors into the ETF
space that may not be used to trading ETFs, you know, they're, they're looking at the best way for
them to buy a block of 20,000 shares for 100 clients and then allocate those 20,000 shares
into those 100 client accounts. Well, because we're a difficult for them if they have a hundred
different prices on those 20,000 shares and they're trying to allocate all that stuff down. And so,
the way advisory systems work, it's easier if they put in a market on open trade, right, because
they're trying to buy and bulk for a number of clients and they're getting it. So those two things
are in conflict, right, the way ETF opens and the way an advisor through their platforms would normally
buy shares. Um, and so one of the, the real major benefit to going to the floor is you're taking
the computer out of it and you're inserting a live individual back into it. And so if I'm Steve
Cook who is the ETF issuer and, and your Brad and your, the market maker on the floor in the
morning, you could look and say, okay, I know there's an advisory trade coming out of Fidelier,
Schwab or or Commonwealth or one of these other platforms. I know it's not a professional trader
trying to pick me off. This is just a person trying to buy 20,000 shares with ETF, a fair price for
their opinion. I'm going to then do my own homework, Brad's going to do his own homework,
look at all the other on ETFs in there and, and he's going to say, okay, I know this is a good trade.
I'm going to open it and I'm going to trade it at two cents above what I think the fair value is
and so you've taken away the whole mystery of avoiding the first 15 minutes market on the open
and the last 15 minutes market on close and you're providing a fair price because there's
somebody who's, you know, manually inserted in that process and could look to make a fair market for
folks. Yeah, I mean, for us, I think it was one of the best things we've done. I mean, the only
thing that kept me up at night about this business was those opens and closes and, and, you know,
we were halted once, you got wild swings and somebody was throwing in over the counter market
on close orders and just just throwing us around and I can say at least for myself,
it was probably one of the best decisions we've made and I, I'm looking at kind of your products
as well as seems like it's, it starts. It really has, when we were seeing some advisors put in
30,000 share orders and get the execution 10 cents away from where it should, right?
So immediately, you know, the order magnitude there, you get a number of the, you're talking
your costing investors, tens of thousands of dollars a year in, in, in market making spreads.
And there's, it's not necessary. And so if we could pay a little bit more to have a human being
inserted in the middle of that trade and save our investors money and make it easier for advisors
to get in and out because we have to meet advisors where they are. Obviously it's better for them to
trade that way. It's easier for them to trade that way for their clients. So we got to make sure
that if they put in at 931 and market on the open order or at 359 and market on close order
that they're going to get good execution and by moving down to the floor, it really has done that
and we've seen it. Well, you know, there's been no trade that's done, market on open above
three cents on any of our ETFs that are on the floor now. And so I think if we start to encounter
those trades more frequently in our other products, we'll continue to move more, more of our ETFs
to the floor for a better client experience. Yeah, that's really what it's about, a better client
experience. And, you know, I couldn't see us launching anything that wasn't
floor traded just because of how our products are in the size and, but let's pivot. We're here
to talk about, uh, hedge your HGER, which is a commodity all weather ETF. So can you talk about
what the ETF is trying to accomplish in the strategy, you know, sure. So, um, you know, this is one of
those firms that after we've launched a few products, we are our present Christophe Lace,
and that relationship, preview with some of the senior folks at Quantix, and they reached out.
And, you know, we've been looking at all of the products that are available to investors
that investing commodities and are meant to protect investors from it. And, and they're all based
on P.K. or G.S.C.I. Bloomberg Mighty Index, or Boban Mighty Index. And, those particular indices
were were created for the purpose of protecting investors against inflation, or giving investors
exposure to these to help them during periods of inflation. They were created for manufacturing
and other firms that use commodities in their daily business to hedge their businesses against,
you know, swings in commodity. And so, everything that's out there, you know, wasn't purpose built
for the reason it's being utilized. And we think there's a better solution that we can create
for investors to give them exposure to commodities during periods of inflation that will protect
the portfolio. And so, that was kind of the genesis of the why. Now, um, the folks at Quantix
commodities, Don Castoro, Matt Schwab, and a number of other folks have a long history, um,
Don Ren, the commodities trading desk for Goldman Sachs for 20 plus years, uh, and all the people at
Quantix were were principles and partners or managing directors at Goldman Sachs with a
commodities perspective. So, these folks have a long history in trading and understanding the commodity
market. Uh, and so, they went about and tried to create the, the, the Quantix total return
commodity index in order to, uh, again, create an investible product that gives investors
exposures to commodities, but does so in a way that's going to, um, uh, take the best advantage of,
um, the economic cycle and, and the commodities that get included in the index and the
weightings, um, so that they're protected against inflation. So, can you talk about some of the
holdings that are in the portfolio and what investors will generally see, uh, in invested in?
So, um, the index, uh, can have access to up to 24 commodities, uh, um, you know, at the beginning
of the year, the index community of Quantix looks at kind of, um, the economic weight of a commodity,
um, in the market, um, understands kind of the role you'll dissociate with all the contracts that are
in the, um, the, the index itself and tries to develop the index to optimize, uh, both the exposure
and the liquidity along with the role yield of the prevailing commodity included. And then the last piece
is, uh, based on either scarcity or, um, or the basement indicators, they will increase or decrease
exposure to precious metals in particular goals. Uh, and so, uh, in general, um, you're getting
broad exposure to petroleum and energy, heating oil, Brent, West Texas, Egypt, gas oil, um,
some, um, smaller but certainly present in grains and soybean products like corn and wheat,
soybeans, uh, soil, uh, some softer commodity exposure, uh, in cotton and sugar, um, right now there's
no, uh, livestock exposure, but there is a bit of habit, and then in base metals, copper,
aluminum, nickel, zinc, uh, and then, as I said, there's about a 30% uh, current exposure to gold,
and all of these things, uh, can be increased, increased, again, depending on the outlook,
the scarcity of those commodities and whether, uh, there are signals of, uh, the basement or
not. So when you, is the portfolio active or is it, uh, more of a rule space, kind of passive portfolio?
So it's a rule of base passive portfolio, um, you know, in theory, but in practice, the underlying
index itself is what we would call actively management. So harbor, you know, uh, history and
believes in management, but we do have some index, you know, base ETFs, but even the ones that we
look at that are indexed based structurally, we think of them as active because they're, we're
actively managing the underlying rule set within the index. And I think that's important, um, you know,
particularly redger, um, although it's rule of based, there's enough dynamism in the underlying
construction of the index, uh, and there's enough, um, input into the rules that define it
that you're going to get quasi-active management within the index structure. So how often is that,
uh, index kind of reconstituting itself, um, and making change. So it'll reconstit in terms of the
actual commodities that can get included in the index on an annual basis, uh, but it will rebound
itself on a quarterly basis. And so, you know, the rules that govern, um, debasement, or scarcity,
get looked at on a quarterly basis, and you will dynamically increase your decrease allocations to
all the commodities and gold based on what's happening in the market at that particular time,
and how the rules are interpreting on a cycle. Got it. So when you're sitting down, you're talking
with advisors about this product, where are you trying to fit this in terms of an overall
model portfolio allocation? You know, we think that investors and advisors, um, for a number of
different reasons, have structurally underweighted, uh, allocation to commodities in the full, you know,
uh, to the top. Um, and in particular, over this last inflationary cycle, they, you know,
advisors and investors have been really underweighted to commodities. Uh, but there's a lot of
reasons for that, right? Again, I think you look at the choices that traditionally advisors had to
allocate to commodities, and there weren't really a lot of good solutions. Uh, there's certainly
weren't many solutions that allowed them to allocate to one product and get dynamic exposure to gold
and none of the other offerings really took into account the potential for role yield within
the underlying commodity allocation. And so, um, you know, for those reasons in the past,
advisors have a lot of bad memories and nightmares of previous allocations to commodities for
their clients. Uh, and so they generally try to shine them a little bit. Um, and so, you know,
our conversations are all around. This is why this is a better product. This is why we kind of
constructed it the way we did. Um, you're going to get a natural allocation to gold when you need it
for your clients. You don't have to worry about trying to time the market. The index itself will
increase their periods of debasement, decrease when there's really scarcity, which means, you know,
not enough commodities to go around. Um, and, but it will provide you with the comfort to know
that you're going to get that allocation to commodities to protect your investors portfolios
against, uh, against inflation. And, and, and it really is work. Right. You look at the last, you know,
18 months of, of hedger being, it's done what it says it's going to do. It's outperformed almost
all other commodity indices and products that are in a market. Um, and, and, and done so in a way
where it's dynamically increased or decreased if the allocation to gold, um, that's, that's kind of
helped them. And so our argument is, you know, you should probably have an allocation around 68% of
your clients portfolio in commodities. You know, maybe a little bit higher right now because of the
fed inflation. Um, doesn't always mean you have to, but you can continue to hold this throughout
other cycles because of some of the other base metal and manufacturing, um, that are in there.
Yeah. I mean, it's a really interesting product. Um, and, you know, you've recently crossed
the $100 million mark. So, congratulations. Um, look about what the distribution efforts had to
look like in order to get there and some of the behind the scenes. Because we talked to a lot of
ETF issuers here and, you know, the easy part is getting the market. The hard part is finding
your market and, and growing. So, uh, I do see you guys are pretty active, um, out, you know,
out there telling your story. So, um, can you talk about what your distribution should look like?
Yeah. So, you know, you know, as well as anybody that there are kind of stages to the distribution
process for an ETF, right? As you articulated, the launch is the easy part, you know, getting the
first couple million bucks in there is a great seeding and it's very easy. Um, and then it just really
become a challenge to get to certain breakpoints or levels where your product can become more
available across more platforms. Uh, and so, you know, the, the, the magic is trying to identify advisors
who don't have cumbersome, uh, gates that won't allow them to invest in a product early on in
this life cycle. If they think it's a good product and if it adds something. And so, you have to work
to find investors and advisors who will jump in early on your products, you know, that's zero to 25
million in assets because many of them simply won't talk to you. If there's, you know, two million
dollars that yours in there and it trades, you know, two shares a day. Um, and so you just kind of
have to continue to tell the story. Um, you know, we've, we've launched our ETF products and built
out our sales team kind of at the same time. Um, you know, we had a much smaller, uh, whole sale and
team and internal whole selling team and we kind of kind of built that out as we've launched the
product and it's been cut that would be good. Um, you know, we've identified some of those, uh,
early advisors who were willing to jump in early. You got it to 25 million. Then you add, uh, you know,
more advisors who really like the story and you're telling it constantly in the market and just going
back to them and so, okay, when you hit 25 million, come back, you know, I'll be interested in doing it.
And they might allocate a little bit at that point, right? And then it's hand to hand combat with a
50 million. And then once you get the 50 million, more of the independent platforms and, you know,
well, I have to talk to the third advisory network about it and you'll start showing up. Uh, and so,
um, you know, you just add a little bit and, and then as you know, the kind of magic number is $100
million. Once you've reached that $100 million threshold, now I'll certainly get on some of the
larger, more nationally recognized distribution and advisory platforms. And then you really have a
story that you've been telling 18 months, all of a sudden becomes a little bit more real.
And these folks are saying, okay, I told you, yeah, when, you know, when you get to certain levels,
you can come back and talk to me. And now all of a sudden, you know, the pipeline, the opportunity
pipeline kind of explodes because, you know, you've been telling the stories for 18 months, people see
it working, but they're waiting for that period of time where they're able to actually go in and
now you're starting to see that. So this is where it really gets exciting. Brad, you know, I mean,
you're starting to see kind of folks say, okay, you got to the $100 million number, now I'm going
to allocate that opportunity pipeline is really growing quickly. Yeah, no, that's, that's great. I mean,
we're, we're kind of at that same threshold now. And it's funny, you know, trying to solve the business
scale, you know, scale issues as you start to grow, right? And an institutionalized the business a
little bit more and trying to find salespeople. So it is a fun business, but again, congratulations.
And before you kind of let you go, you guys have a full suite of product. There's a lot of them.
So we don't need to go through them all. But one other ETFs or products may be set up well,
kind of currently that advisors should be looking at, get environment that we're in.
Yeah, so we have an international equity product, tickers OC, S-E-A, run by a firm
out of your, called C-Worldwide, the interesting international ETF. They have a defined process.
You know, they have a, a competition for capital as they call it. They will only ever own 30 stocks
in the portfolio. So it's a nice concentrated. These are large global businesses that when you look at it,
really want to own. You want to have exposure to. As folks are seeking out returns and uncoorrelated
terms, looking at international products that are, that are owned businesses that you want,
not just for diversification, but because they're really well run. And and C-Worldwide looks at it
as international compounders. So folks and, and management teams that kind of compound the success
of their business over time by reinvesting the capital or the stewards of capital. So that's a
really interesting portfolio should really strong returns over the last 12 months and we just
pulled my part there. So we're really excited about, as a product. And then two other larger equity
portfolios win, which is large kept growth ETF that we've launched with Johnson Associates
and G-Div, which is a both dividend portfolio that we launched with our partners at Westfield.
That was actually a mutual fund that we converted so it's a long track record there. But if you combine
those two ETFs in the investors portfolio to offer kind of the growth aspect along with the defensive
equity portion of it, those are really nice compliments when you kind of put the portfolios together
in in a client's portfolio. So, you know, we're really excited about as you noted all the ETFs
that we have. But we think those four in general provide a really nice set of core holdings for
investors as they look out the next 24 months through the the various kind of business cycles that we
could see, you know, whether it's higher for longer or, you know, a soft landing, you know,
combining those four and the right allocations provides investors with a unique set of returns
that we think are going to be really good for investors portfolios. Yeah, that's great, Steven.
We'll have to have either you or somebody else from your team or one of your asset managers
back to talk about a couple of those products and you guys keep innovating. So I'm sure we'll have
you back. But before I let you go, I just want to say thank you for doing this and where can people
learn more about bonds over there at Harbor? Brad, again, thanks for having me on. It's always a
lot of fun to talk about ETFs. We all have a lot of energy and enthusiasm for this space. And so,
you know, customers love to talk about it. But you can find out all the products that we have listed
on both ETF and mutual funds side at HarborCapelAdvisors.herheartlevel.com.
Great. Well, again, Steve, thanks so much and hope to see you soon.
